reviewText: This DVD release marked Pavarotti's 75th anniversary on 12 October 2010.The performance was made in December 1978, when Pavarotti was in his prime days.James Conlon conducted the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra and Chorus, and in the title role is Shirely Verrett, the great American mezzo.Tosca is a spinto role that could well be tackled by a spinto soprano or mezzo and Verrett is the latter. But by 1978, Verett's timbre in the lower sections was used, and it shows here quite clearly. Her portrayal is otherwise a very fine one.American baritone MacNeil portrayed Scarpia, and for most part, he is a good match for Pavarotti.While Pavarotti was in his vocal prime at the time this live performance was given, I would hesitate to nominate this as his best Cavaradozzi performance. The duets with Tosca in the first act isn't really emotionally 'on fire' as they should have been. Pav seemed to have pulled back in some of the most intensive musical lines, and the result is the singing is not as arresting as it should and could have been.The production itself is quite fine, to do justice to the MET.Even so, it is still nice to be able to get a historical recording of PAV taken at his prime in a role that he had later came to be so famous in.For this alone, this DVD would be a welcome addition to Pavarotti's fans' musical shelf.
summary: Almost a 'must' for Pavarotti fans, but mark out his collaboration earlier with Kabaivanska, too.

reviewText: With the exception of Patricia Racette, Shirley Verrett's performance as Tosca is the finest. She has Tosca in her soul. And her colleagues are none other than Pavarotti and MacNeil. A triple threat of which Verrett shines brightest.

reviewText: The singing and the orchestra's playing were excellent. Pavarotti's acting. however, is never as excellent as his singing. Verrett was an excellent singing actress for the role of Floria Tosca.

reviewText: Verrett and MacNeil, along with the great Pavarotti in his prime, make a "golden age of singing" cast. Maestro Conlon deserves mention for his intense conducting and superior musicianship! The only drawback is that this was before the days of HD, so the picture isn't perfect.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I don't understand how the previous reviewer can wax so euphorically over Pavarotti here, and then complain about Verrett's "limitations".  I seriously question that judgement.  Miss Verrett, who passed away just days ago, was the reason why I purchased this DVD.  It's easy to understand why she has been referred to as "the black Callas".  Her Tosca is electric, magnetic, extremely well sung, and magnificently executed.  Her singing is consistently compelling, and her portrayal of the doomed diva is every bit as three dimensional as that of Callas.  For me, SHE'S the reason to acquire this performance.  Pavarotti, of course, is Pavarotti.  His singing is undeniably beautiful.  His stage movements, however, are downright staid, and he certainly doesn't produce the stage electricity that Verrett does.  Cornell MacNeil is a resonant Scarpia, and sounds somewhat better than on his later DVD performance with Hildegarde Behrens --- but he nails down the role and plays it for all it's worth.  James Conlon does a fine job with the orchestra, providing the appropriate tension and tautness, yet allowing his singers (and what singers they are!) plenty of room to make their much-appreciated effects.  I heartily recommend this DVD for Verrett.  How unfortunate that it has become a memorial to her greatness as an artist.

reviewText: Most likely the best Tosca on DVD.Reason is the superb Tosca of Shirley Verrett.All components do come together and everyone is excellent.However does anyone buy a Tosca DVD because of the Tenor/etc.?
Title: N/A

reviewText: Being an inveterate Pavarotti fan,  how could I NOT buy this DVD despite the fact that "Tosca" is not one of my favorite operas. However, the only "impressive" moment came right at the beginning when Pavarotti first comes unto the scene, fleet-footed and practically leaping into view. We are so used to see a much slower Pavarotti.Otherwise, this DVD added nothing to existing DVDs and CDs of this opera. It is neither special nor exciting and if anything, it belongs to Cornel Macneal - a positively towering, evil-dripping Scarpia.In comparison with Pavarotti's later "Tosca" with Kabaivanska from Rome, despite the awful production and Ingmar Wixell's Scarpia who cannot hold a candle to Macneal's, I find this latter one far more alive and engaging.Steffi B. Rath
